content.webTitle: Cable & Wireless under threat as Scots circle

fields.headline: Cable & Wireless under threat as Scots circle
fields.bodyText: Thus, the Glasgow-based telecoms group, could launch a takeover bid for beleaguered Cable & Wireless, according to City bankers. The company is understood to be looking at two options: first, a takeover of C&W's British business, valued at next to nothing by analysts, but with a pensions deficit of nearly £200m. Bankers say Thus would plug part of the deficit, although C&W could make a sizeable contribution, as it is selling overseas operations expected to fetch £350m. A second option would see Thus take over all of C&W, which includes a lucrative network in the Caribbean. But that would cost up to £3bn and need backing from a private equity group such as Carlyle of the US. Thus, headed by Bill Allan, is not ready to make its move - the sums do not add up for either the company or private equity until C&W's share price falls below 100p. On Friday, the shares were trading at 107p. C&W's prospects look dire. Last week it said it planned to axe 2,000 to 3,000 of its 5,500 British workforce and slash customer numbers by 90 per cent to reduce costs. C&W, like Thus, provides telephony and internet services to businesses, but there is overcapacity and severe downward pressure on pricing. C&W is expected to be ejected from the FTSE 100 index this week, along with Daily Mail & General Trust, whose share price has fallen since it pulled the sale of its Northcliffe regional newspaper division.
